name: Kepler-184
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-184 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-184 is a star with 0.765 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.87 times its radius. It is located 2026.21 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-184 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-184 b

Kepler-184 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 10.69 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-184.

The mass of Kepler-184 b is 7.59 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-184 b is 2.36 that of Earth. At 7.59 Earth masses, Kepler-184 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-184 c

Kepler-184 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 20.30 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-184.

The mass of Kepler-184 c is 4.91 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-184 c is 1.97 that of Earth. At 4.91 Earth masses, Kepler-184 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-184 d

Kepler-184 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.18 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 29.02 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-184.

The mass of Kepler-184 d is 8.58 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-184 d is 2.49 that of Earth. At 8.58 Earth masses, Kepler-184 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-184, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
